Award.AwardTitle: PIRE: A US-China partnership in research and education of intraplate earthquakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Partnerships for International Research and Education (PIRE) 2007
ABSTRACT

Proposal No: 0730154
PI: Mian Liu
Institution: University of Missouri-Columbia
Title: PIRE: A US-China partnership in research and education of intraplate earthquakes

This PIRE (integrated international research and education) project joins the U.S. and Chinese partners in a five-year project to investigate what causes large intraplate earthquakes in North China and improve understanding of intraplate seismicity in the New Madrid region of the Unit4ed States. The PIRE will fund an extensive program of faculty and student research to jointly image crustal and mantle structure, measure crustal deformation, and explore earthquake physics generally. Mian Liu, Professor in the Department of Geosciences at the University of Missouri, Columbia, leads a partnership with three other U.S. institutions: the University of Oklahoma, University of Colorado, and North Carolina State University. The project will train 23 graduate students, 20 undergraduate students and 50 science teachers on the U.S. side during its five-year course. The Chinese partners are CHEN, Yongshun, Institute of Geophysics at Peking University, WANG, Liangshu, Department of Earth Sciences, Nanjing University, Nanjing, and SHI, Yaolin, College of Earth Sciences, Graduate School of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing. The project will benefit the broader geosciences community through the production of data sets, computer models and curriculum materials.

The project combines geodetic techniques including passive and active seismic imaging, crustal motion (GPS and InSAR), earthquake geology (trenching and marine paleoseismology) and geodynamic modeling. The China Earthquake Administration and associated Chinese scientists contribute a new seismic network, drilling, field support and complementary expertise. The project has a plan for recruiting underrepresented minorities at the student level, and will impact a large number of K-12 science teachers, students and the broader public via workshops, summer institutes, curriculum development, and other outreach activities.

This project is co-funded with two programs in the Directorate for Geosciences: the Opportunities for Enhancing Diversity in the Geosciences (OEDG) program, and the Surface Earth Processes Program of the Division of Earth Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was to understand earthquakes in mid-continents (such as central and eastern US), using North China as the natural laboratory. Over the course of his project our research activities have been focused on the following areas: 1) Active source seismology – students and faculty from University of Oklahoma conducted two joint field experiments with Chinese partners; 2) Passive source seismology – focus of this effort was on data processing during the reported year; Active Tectonics – students and faculty from University of Missouri trenched fault zones in China to reconstruct earthquake history, and 4) Geodynamics – we investigated large earthquakes and their aftershocks in China and studied the 20 April 2013 Lushan earthquake (Mw 6.6).. Over the course of the project we made major progress using all of these techniques. We discovered new aspects to the timing and location of major earthquakes that are fundamentally different from those at plate boundaries (Figures 1 and 2).  We have combined passive-source seismology with active-source seismology to image the crustal and lithospheric structure in North China and along the edge of the Tibetan plateau (Figures 3 and 4), where large intraplate earthquakes are frequent and often damaging, including the 2008 Wenchuan earthquake on the eastern margin of  the Tibetan Plateau.  We studied stress and strain energy evolution that lead to this earthquake, and reassessed earthquake hazard in this region.

 

In addition we have run two workshops that focused on earthquakes in the central U.S. and earthquakes in general.  Each of these workshops were attended by 20 high school science teachers from Missouri and other midwest states.  We also took more than a dozen US undergraduate students to China, they spend a month there study earthquakes sites and exchange with Chinese faculty and students. In addition to this, this project involved at least 15 graduate students who successfully completed their degrees.
